channel.title: yudel tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from yudel.

item.description: @dzkalman @shaisecunda This comes back to the sampling question. If there are a thousand frum Jews in town, and one is a landlord with ten thousand rental units, most appliance installations by a frum Jew will be by a landlord.
item.source:markdown: @dzkalman @shaisecunda This comes back to the sampling question. If there are a thousand frum Jews in town, and one is a landlord with ten thousand rental units, most appliance installations by a frum Jew will be by a landlord.

item.description: @bruces This is the future our railroad timetables want.
item.source:markdown: @bruces This is the future our railroad timetables want.

item.description: @bruces Isn’t this more like vitamins — probably useless pills that have a long shot possible payoff but can be easily budgeted because you don’t need to keep upping the dosage?
item.source:markdown: @bruces Isn’t this more like vitamins — probably useless pills that have a long shot possible payoff but can be easily budgeted because you don’t need to keep upping the dosage?

item.description: @dzkalman Spoken like an out-of-towner. What do you mean, “other cities”?
item.source:markdown: @dzkalman Spoken like an out-of-towner. What do you mean, “other cities”?

item.description:
@dzkalman If you have 10 bad landlords and two are Orthodox Jews — as would happen on the old Village Voice lists — and let’s assume for a moment the list is based on an “objective” count of violations —

@dzkalman Then the two Jews will stand out more than the eight gentiles. But what is the real question?

@dzkalman Are a higher proportion of Jewish landlords bad than gentile landlords?

@dzkalman Are a higher percentage of Jews landlords, so even if each Jewish landlord is only half as likely to be bad as a gentile, there are still a disproportionate number of bad Jewish landlords?

@dzkalman And if there’s an implicit claim that being a religious Jew conveys virtue in a universal sense, isn’t one bad landlord sufficient to rebut that claim?

@dzkalman And given the tendency of Orthodox religious leaders to stereotype other groups — cf Avigdor Miller and RHS — is it appropriate for them to cry foul when they’re stereotyped in turn?

@dzkalman Haven’t there been studies showing people have a limited amount of goodness? And if you exhaust yours keeping two sets of dishes, casual fraud is that much harder to resist.

@dzkalman Thinking now of a scion of a well known modern Orthodox family whose financial records I had occasion to review. An awful lot of personal expenses paid by the business that weren’t reported as income on Schedule C.
item.source:markdown:
@dzkalman Haven’t there been studies showing people have a limited amount of goodness? And if you exhaust yours keeping two sets of dishes, casual fraud is that much harder to resist.
@dzkalman Thinking now of a scion of a well known modern Orthodox family whose financial records I had occasion to review. An awful lot of personal expenses paid by the business that weren’t reported as income on Schedule C.

item.description: “ I think that the serious psychological health of Jewish women is more important to Jewish law than encouraging stricter observance of Noahide law. “ https://t.co/4nA1OUqraC

item.description:
@jaymichaelson I suspect there may be a lot of Republican Jews who may be unpleasantly surprised by the rolling back of the Constitution to the 19th century, as much as they will applaud the return of child labor and the return of disproportional representation.

@jaymichaelson It’s not obvious that Maryland’s restriction of office holders to Christians wouldn’t pass constitutional muster given the current court’s stated principles.
item.source:markdown:
@jaymichaelson I suspect there may be a lot of Republican Jews who may be unpleasantly surprised by the rolling back of the Constitution to the 19th century, as much as they will applaud the return of child labor and the return of disproportional representation.
@jaymichaelson It’s not obvious that Maryland’s restriction of office holders to Christians wouldn’t pass constitutional muster given the current court’s stated principles.

item.description:
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer There used to be such people. They fought government suppression of speech at the Supreme Court and, in the 60s and 70s, decisively won. I expect we’ll see such people again soon at the Supreme Court, decisively losing in the 20s and 30s.

@AlexandraErin @tompeyer Ms. Paul is making their work harder.
item.source:markdown:
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer There used to be such people. They fought government suppression of speech at the Supreme Court and, in the 60s and 70s, decisively won. I expect we’ll see such people again soon at the Supreme Court, decisively losing in the 20s and 30s.
@AlexandraErin @tompeyer Ms. Paul is making their work harder.
